title: WMBD Prep Sports Recap: Jan. 5, 2026
description: PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD) ‚Äì While most of Central Illinois was focused on Illinois State in the FCS national championship game Monday night, there were still a handful of high school basketball contests. Washington boys beat Streator 57-28, with James Johnson and Jackson Vanderheydt each scoring 10. Also, Farmington boys beat Delavan 61-44. On the girls [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD) ‚Äì While most of Central Illinois was focused on Illinois State in the FCS national championship game Monday night, there were still a handful of high school basketball contests.

Washington boys beat Streator 57-28, with James Johnson and Jackson Vanderheydt each scoring 10. Also, Farmington boys beat Delavan 61-44.

On the girls side, Dee-Mack defeated Heyworth 43-33 in a battle of two conference foes who game into the game 14-1 on the year. Dalia DeJesus led the Chiefs with 14.

Eureka also beat Heyworth and Tri-Valley defeated Olympia.

title: Unbeatens SF Christian, West Central meet in GOTW
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (KELO) ‚Äî The first KELOLAND Sports Game of the Week for the basketball season is a battle of unbeatens as West Central travels to take on reigning Class ‚ÄòA‚Äô state champion Sioux Falls Christian. Coverage begins at 7 p.m.
fullText:
SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (KELO) ‚Äî The first KELOLAND Sports Game of the Week for the basketball season is a battle of unbeatens as West Central travels to take on reigning Class ‚ÄòA‚Äô state champion Sioux Falls Christian.

Coverage begins at 7 p.m. Tuesday night on KELOXTRA, KELOLAND.com and KELOLAND+.

Top-ranked SFC is 3-0 and has won 13 straight games dating back to last season. It defeated Lennox by 26 to open the season, then routed Elk Point-Jefferson by 53 and topped Huron 66-61 in its most recent game last Tuesday.

Brant Wassenaar leads the Chargers with 21.3 points and 6.3 rebounds per game. Cooper Goodbary is also averaging double figures with 13 points, five rebounds, 2.6 assists and two steals a night.

The Trojans are ranked No. 2 in Class ‚ÄòA‚Äô and boast a 6-0 record. They won all three of their games last week and are averaging 78 points per game this season. West Central is winning by an average of 38.8 points per game.

Three players are averaging in double figures. Connor Mebius leads the way with 18.5 points a game. Big man Will Kuhl contributes 15.7 points and 6.8 rebounds a night. Hayden Heier chips in 12 points per game.

Sioux Falls Christian has won the last five meetings in the series. West Central‚Äôs last win came back in December 2021.

Play-by-play and commentary will be provided by KELOLAND‚Äôs Grant Sweeter and Ian Sacks.

title: What does Browns firing Kevin Stefanski mean for Shedeur Sanders?
description:
The organization planted seeds of doubt about the Browns‚Äô answer to the most impactful position in sports.
Neither GM Andrew Berry nor team owner Jimmy Haslam endorsed Sanders as their 2026 answer.
fullText:
On a day when the Cleveland Browns knew fans wanted answers and accountability, team brass didn‚Äôt hide the direction the franchise must go.

‚ÄúThe offense, it‚Äôs no secret that‚Äôs where we‚Äôre going to invest most of our resources this offseason,‚Äù general manager Andrew Berry said.

Team owner Jimmy Haslam agreed that ‚Äúwe have a lot of work to do on the roster, particularly on the offensive side of the roster.‚Äù

That neither man crowned any quarterback on their roster as the 2026 leader was telling ‚Äî not because Shedeur Sanders, Dillon Gabriel and Deshaun Watson have no chance, but because it is clear that none of them has a guarantee.

A new head coach will arrive in Cleveland soon, after the Browns fired Kevin Stefanski after six seasons featured a 45-56 (.446) regular-season record.

That coach will have meaningful say on who starts at quarterback for the Browns next season and what will be most highly valued at the position.

[Get more Browns news: Cleveland team feed]

That the Browns will hire an offensive-minded head coach to develop that quarterback is no guarantee: The job will be ‚Äúto make sure that the offense is run and developed well,‚Äù Berry said, ‚Äúas opposed to necessarily having to be the person that directly does it.‚Äù

But losing, particularly in three- and five-win seasons the last two years, cost Stefanski his job. And the Browns know that finding a lasting quarterback answer is the No. 1 factor that will correlate with turning around their win total.

No one is saying aloud that Sanders, Gabriel and Watson cannot be the answer. But the organization planted seeds of doubt Monday about the Browns‚Äô answer to the most impactful position in sports.

Neither Berry nor Haslam endorsed Sanders, their starter to end the season, as their 2026 answer. The next head coach will have a say, and Sanders himself acknowledged that ‚Äúwhen it comes to those grown-up decisions that‚Äôs not me.‚Äù

What the Browns do know, and were willing to say, is that they need an answer quickly.

‚ÄúAt the end of the day, the National Football League is a quarterback league, right?‚Äù seven-time Pro Bowl left guard Joel Bitonio said. ‚ÄúIf you have an elite quarterback in this league, it allows you to be a little bit more sustained in your success. And it's not me saying like, ‚ÄòDo we know if Shedeur or Dillon or Deshaun or Bailey [Zappe], any of these guys is that guy,‚Äô right?

‚ÄúWe have those guys in our locker room. But until you have a guy that can stay healthy and can be on the field and be that guy for your team, it's hard to have that sustained success. ‚Ä¶

‚ÄúUntil you find one that's stable and can lead your team, it's going to be hard to not ride the roller coaster of wins and losses.‚Äù

The Browns do not regret that they evaluated and practiced with four quarterbacks during the offseason and training camp.

Considering depth was not the problem. Missing on a higher ceiling was.

‚ÄúWe believe in competition in every room on the roster, and quarterback‚Äôs no different,‚Äù Berry said. ‚ÄúQuarterback is the most important position in sports. We all know that. And part of the equation with quarterback is the evaluation part. Part of it is the development part as well.‚Äù

The Browns traded away the second overall pick in the 2025 NFL Draft rather than spend a premium pick on quarterback as some expected. Later in the draft, they selected two quarterbacks ‚Äî Gabriel in the third round followed by Sanders in the fifth. It was a curious move. And yet, Berry believes philosophically in expending significant resources at quarterback.

‚ÄúI wouldn't necessarily say draft a quarterback every year, I don't believe it being that,‚Äù Berry told Yahoo Sports last June from minicamp. ‚ÄúBut if you're in position to make a bet on a quarterback that you think can be a quality starter or some level of high-level proficiency, understand that it's not always going to pan out. That's a bet you should be making because you just never know.‚Äù

The philosophy suggests the Browns will not stay put at quarterback this spring, the question of their acquisition more a question of how rather than if. In their 2025 season, the Browns recognized their transitional stage and built up the roster at some positions. But while their defense posted its second top-five unit in three years, the Browns‚Äô offense ranked bottom-five in offense for the second straight season.

A year after ranking last in scoring, the Browns ranked second-to-last this year. In what Berry and Haslam described as a year of roster ‚Äútransition,‚Äù the franchise evaluated its rookies at length.

The Browns won three of Sanders‚Äô seven games compared to one of Gabriel's six, wins often considered the ‚Äúmost important‚Äù quarterback statistic. In traditional quarterback stats, their performance was mixed.

Sanders averaged 193 passing yards per start compared to Gabriel‚Äôs 153, while completing 59.5% of his attempts to Gabriel‚Äôs 58.9%. But Sanders‚Äô 0.8 touchdown-to-interception ratio (seven touchdowns, nine interceptions in seven games) paled in comparison to Gabriel‚Äôs 3.0 (six touchdowns to two interceptions in six games). Sanders‚Äô 72.9 passer rating trailed Gabriel‚Äôs 78.9.

Sanders earned the right to continue starting and warranting evaluation through season‚Äôs end. But with below-league-average metrics, the Browns are not saying right now that he‚Äôs earned the right to start next season.

‚ÄúWe saw a lot of progress with Shedeur this year,‚Äù Berry said. ‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs both mentally, physically, playing the position. He‚Äôs still very much a work in progress like many rookie quarterbacks are. But I think we saw some really good things in terms of his playmaking, his accuracy, his ability to extend [plays] with his feet. And I think I‚Äôd also give him credit as well as our offensive staff for bringing him along in terms of his pocket management, his situational awareness and things of that nature.

‚ÄúNow that all being said, we‚Äôre going to do our work on the quarterback market. It‚Äôs too important of a position and it‚Äôs something that has to be solidified. I can‚Äôt sit here and tell you today, you know, whether the solution for or the starter in 2026 is internal or external. But it‚Äôs something that we‚Äôre going to work through over the next several weeks. And quite honestly, the new head coach will also have a lot of input into that as well.‚Äù

Perhaps the best thing the Browns can do for their quarterback future is hire the coach they best believe will lead their organization, independent of any single quarterback style.

Berry acknowledged that ‚Äúschemes, they really do come and go.‚Äù An NFC assistant coach whose team helped their quarterback rebound after a coaching change felt no single schematic factor was the answer in their club.

‚ÄúI think they just need to find the best coach possible,‚Äù the assistant told Yahoo Sports. ‚ÄúYou just need to hire the best guy for each job of the organization vs. being predetermined to get a QB guru or whatever you think you need stylistically.

‚ÄúThat way you‚Äôre able to pivot if it turns out [the quarterback] isn‚Äôt the guy, but at least you hired the right coach.‚Äù

This year‚Äôs sophomore quarterback class is evidence of that.

Setting a historic pace, teams selected six quarterbacks in the first 12 picks of the 2024 NFL Draft. Second overall pick Jayden Daniels took the Commanders to the NFC Championship game in his first season under center. This year, three more 2024 quarterbacks have led their teams to a playoff berth.

Selected at first, third and 12th respectively, Caleb Williams, Drake Maye and Bo Nix vary in style and NFL early-career experience. While Nix arrived to an organization with coaching stability, receiving play calls from Super Bowl-winning Sean Payton, his counterparts each entered Year 2 with a new head coach. Their two coaching r√©sum√©s differ vastly, Ben Johnson a first-time head coach who‚Äôs calling offensive plays while Mike Vrabel is a second-time head coach calling plays on neither side of the ball.

And yet, talent evaluators around the league look at each of their stories and see the success stemming from coach at least as much as quarterback. The ‚Äúright‚Äù coach was hired. Neither his quality or quantity of experience determined whether he was the right coach.

Finding Mr. Right will be Berry‚Äôs job in the coming weeks, after which the group will decide how and with whom they want to augment the quarterback room. Doing nothing, while currently on track for a host of 2026 draft picks, including the sixth overall as well as a late first-round selection, would be shocking.

While free agency is always an option, 12 of the 14 starting quarterbacks in this year‚Äôs postseason were selected in the first round. Three are no longer with the team that initially drafted them, a reminder of success teams have had in recent years finding quarterbacks via trade or free agency.

That history may be a tell for the Browns brass‚Äôs next move. And it may be a tell of Sanders‚Äô chance at keeping his starting job through 2026. Fifth-round quarterbacks face uphill battles. So do quarterbacks selected before a coach had input in that decision.

‚ÄúI think overall, like as a quarterback, I showed different pieces in different games to all add up to one complete quarterback,‚Äù Sanders said. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs what I had to get to in those situations ‚Äî red-zone situations, field-goal situations, third-down situations, ‚Äòwhere you at on the field‚Äô situations. So, it was a lot of situations that was good. I feel like this was a good learning year for me, and I‚Äôm excited for it. Because like I say, like moving forward I‚Äôll be prepared.

‚ÄúI did what I was able to do, and I definitely grew from a lot of things. And I got experience now. So, I‚Äôm always the same: confidence-wise, I‚Äôm there. But like, that‚Äôs not in my hands. Like, that‚Äôs not my decision.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt speak on what other people feel.‚Äù

title: Is Miami‚Äôs edge rusher Rueben Bain the best player in the 2026 NFL draft?
description: A collection of articles, podcasts & tweets from around the web to keep you in touch with the Commanders, the NFC East, the NFL and sports in general, and a sprinkling of other stuff
fullText:
We have elevated DT Ricky Barber and WR River Cracraft from the practice squad pic.twitter.com/LnFS6NHTYI

‚Äî Washington Commanders (@Commanders) January 3, 2026

Kingsbury will be a hot name this offseason despite having a down year for the Commanders, but will he actually leave? He‚Äôs already been linked to the Tennessee Titans and Las Vegas Raiders job as a fit, but what about going to a division rival? ESPN‚Äôs Jordan Raanan said the Giants will cast a wide net in their head coaching search, but Kingsbury might be on the outside looking in.

‚ÄúCommanders‚Äô offensive coordinator Kingsbury, who also has experience as an NFL head coach with the Cardinals, is considered a bright offensive mind. The question is if he‚Äôs the right fit for the New York market.‚Äù ‚Äì Jordan Raanan, ESPN

The Giants interview list includes Mike McCarthy, Chris Shula, Antonio Pierce and more as they cast a wide net. https://t.co/o2weOafxQt

‚Äî Jordan Raanan (@JordanRaanan) January 2, 2026

It would be a surprise if Kingsbury doesn‚Äôt even get an interview with the Giants, given his track record with young quarterbacks, and what he could do with Jaxson Dart. It sounds like they could be interested in Kingsbury, but he‚Äôs likely more of a tier two or tier three candidate for the Giants.

The former TCU standout is getting a look down the stretch with Tunsil out. Coleman looks more accomplished and urgent in everything he does. He is not the finished article by any stretch of the imagination, but his upturn in consistency indicates that all hope is not lost just yet.

This hasn‚Äôt gone unnoticed by Quinn. The coach thinks Coleman has learned a great deal in his second campaign. The athletic upside has always been there, but the lineman has developed a new sense of resilience that is standing him in exceptional stead.

‚ÄúI think‚Ä¶he has learned a lot here in year two. This is a resilient guy that can do a lot of things based on his athleticism, him learning and going through the hard moments.‚ÄùDan Quinn via Commanders.com

Coleman will start at left tackle again in Week 18 against the Philadelphia Eagles if he gets the all-clear to participate. He‚Äôs listed as questionable with a knee problem, but he practiced in full on Friday. That‚Äôs a positive sign, which gives him a fighting chance of finishing his campaign on a high note.

The Commanders elevated Cracraft from the practice squad to the active roster Saturday ahead of Sunday‚Äôs game against the Eagles. Cracraft has been elevated for consecutive weeks, finishing Christmas Day‚Äôs loss against the Cowboys with just one snap on the special-teams unit. With Terry McLaurin, Deebo Samuel, Treylon Burks and Chris Moore all healthy and active, Cracraft is likely in line to see the same minimal special-teams snap share in Sunday‚Äôs game.

1) What were your big takeaways from the Week 16 matchup between the Commanders and Eagles?

I do think it‚Äôs silly how the Commanders took such offense to the Eagles going for two late in the game. Why wait until then to show that kind of fight? Also, laughable to hear Dan Quinn talk tough about how Washington was going to see the Eagles again in two weeks. When it seemed like the Eagles will be resting their starters, which we now know is exactly the case. For Quinn to be afraid of going for it on fourth down (punted on 4th-and-4 from the minus 40-yard line down 11 with 9 minutes to go ‚Ä¶ and punted on 4th-and-6 from the minus 44-yard line down 11 with just 6:44 to go) and then act all tough in the postgame presser? That‚Äôs unserious behavior to me.

2) How far do you think the Eagles will get in the post-season and what do you think will be their biggest secret to success or stumbling block?

I think the Eagles can win the Super Bowl. Vic Fangio‚Äôs defense is awesome. Jalen Hurts has played well in the biggest games of his career. There is no juggernaut the Eagles simply can‚Äôt beat.

Do you expect the Commanders will try especially hard this week or are they going to pack it in and rest key players with an eye to the 2026 season? How do fans want the team to approach this game?

I don‚Äôt know that the Commanders will try especially hard to win, but they will certainly try as hard to win as they did in the last matchup (where the playoffs were already out of reach). Reports are that Dan Quinn still has the locker room, the players are still bought in, and the coaches and players still want to win games. So I‚Äôm sure they‚Äôll try their hardest to win, just like last time, but the deck will be stacked against them due to all their injuries.

The decision to rest or play starters is not just about protecting players or gaining draft position, it‚Äôs also about putting together some good tape so the front office can actually evaluate the talent on the team. So many players have been injured or are returning from injury, so many players have been moved to different positions or roles (particularly on defense) due to injuries and due to Dan Quinn taking over the defense a few weeks ago, that it‚Äôs probably more important for the front office to get additional tape on these players playing their best in order to evaluate them than it is to get a slightly higher draft spot. What good does a better draft pick do if you can‚Äôt even evaluate your biggest team needs effectively? For this reason, as well as for pride and division rivalry, I think most fans will be rooting for the starters to play and the team to play well. In my opinion, the only reason to tank is if you need a top 2 pick for a QB, quality players at other positions can be found later in the draft.

Tampa Bay‚Äôs 16-14 win over the Panthers keeps it alive, but now the Bucs need the Saints to beat the Falcons to make the postseason.

the showdown game for first place in the NFC South did not yield a division winner, at least not yet.

So it went on the opening day of the final weekend of the NFL‚Äôs regular season. The Seahawks beat the San Francisco 49ers in Santa Clara, California, to secure the NFC West title and the conference‚Äôs No. 1 playoff seed. The Tampa Bay Buccaneers defeated the Carolina Panthers but will have to wait until Sunday to see whether that will be enough for them to win the NFC South.

The playoff field is taking shape and will be fully formed when Sunday‚Äôs play is done.

The Buccaneers helped their postseason cause. But they didn‚Äôt punch their playoff ticket, at least not yet.

The opening game of the final weekend of the NFL‚Äôs regular season did not determine as much as it could have. The Buccaneers beat the Panthers, 16-14, in the rain Saturday at Raymond James Stadium in Tampa. But they will have to wait until Sunday to find out whether they will secure their fifth straight NFC South title and the NFC‚Äôs No. 4 playoff seed.

They need the Atlanta Falcons to lose Sunday to the New Orleans Saints. If the Falcons beat the Saints, that would create a three-way tie for the division lead with matching 8-9 records. The Panthers would win the division in that case, based on tiebreakers.

‚ÄúWe did everything we could today,‚Äù Buccaneers quarterback Baker Mayfield told ESPN afterward. ‚ÄúSit back and see what happens tomorrow.‚Äù

The final show@BankofAmerica | #RaiseHail pic.twitter.com/UoGpgmFVLs

‚Äî Washington Commanders (@Commanders) January 4, 2026

Commanders edge rusher Von Miller needs one sack Sunday vs. the Eagles to finish the season with nine sacks and collect another $500,000 in incentives. pic.twitter.com/eDSPxZ9Lls

‚Äî Adam Schefter (@AdamSchefter) January 4, 2026

Commanders WR Deebo Samuel has $650,000 on the line Sunday vs. the Eagles. Samuel needs 10 catches to collect another $200,000 incentive, 93 receiving yards for another $200,000 and two touchdowns to collect another $250,000. pic.twitter.com/gQrYMPtYg9

‚Äî Adam Schefter (@AdamSchefter) January 4, 2026

Reminder that 49ers had only punted twice since Week 13 coming into this game üò≥

The Seattle defense stepped up pic.twitter.com/15Rz5s3F5l

QBs with back-to-back 14+ win seasons in NFL history:

‚Ä¢ Tom Brady (2003-2004)
‚Ä¢ Sam Darnold (2024-2025)

That‚Äôs the list. https://t.co/VKtzhXl33x pic.twitter.com/wSrqvTUArk

‚Äî Ari Meirov (@MySportsUpdate) January 4, 2026

If the #Chiefs lose Matt Nagy during this year's hiring cycle, a reunion with Eric Bieniemy could receive consideration:https://t.co/YqLW3qaa0E

‚Äî Pro Football Rumors (@pfrumors) January 4, 2026

title: 'Haunted Nancy detached from reality as Celtic's lights go out'
description: BBC Sport Scotland's chief sports writer dissects the outcome of Saturday's Old Firm defeat for Celtic.
fullText:
As he took a slow walk up the Celtic tunnel on full-time, it wasn't hard to feel something for Wilfried Nancy, a haunted manager on the end of a sixth defeat in his eight games. Over-promoted and out of his depth.

A first half at Celtic Park that offered such promise made way for another second half of dismal collapse. They had Rangers on the ropes at the break but you always sensed that they needed a second goal to put them on the floor and maybe a third just to put them out for the count. These are Celtic's frailties these days. One goal is never enough.

Those goals never came despite the chances they had. Once Rangers started to fight back, they hit Celtic with three blows in 21 minutes. Ruthless. The Celtic lights went out in an instant. From light to dark in the blink of an eye.

The colossal weaknesses in Nancy's formation, the giant amounts of space conceded by his players were the problem again. That and their inability to stay in the fight. Was their feeble demise a window to their collective soul, a reflection of their spirit under the new, and surely doomed, manager? It looked like that. A lost dressing room? Perhaps. Just because it's a cliche doesn't mean it isn't true.

title: Letters to Sports: Times are tough for Lincoln Riley and his Trojans
description: Readers of the L.A. Times Sports section share their thoughts on USC losing in the Alamo Bowl, Lincoln Riley's coaching job, college bowl games, the Lakers and Bill Plaschke.
fullText:
It's very obvious to this USC diehard fan, Lincoln Riley is not delivering on his commitment to restore Trojans football to national prominence as head coach.

Stop promising better results, hiring new assistant coaches, and commenting on the difficulty of the schedule.

After USC lost to unranked Texas Christian in the Alamo Bowl to finish a 9-4 season, coach Lincoln Riley said, "The arrow is pointing straight up." He apparently didn't receive a compass for Christmas.

If USC plays again in the Alamo Bowl, the Trojans should bring their own officials. ‚ÄôNuf said.

After losing to TCU in overtime, the Trojans will always "Remember the Alamo (Bowl)." With that, the Men of Troy seem to break my heart every football season. Not playing Notre Dame anymore is sacrilegious. Last but not least, Lincoln Riley is an overrated head football coach. Fight On!

The Ohio State University loses the big playoff game and Ole Miss advances without former coach Lane Kiffin. I imagine millions, like me, hope Ole Miss will win the whole thing without Kiffin.

Times sports columnist Bill Plaschke appropriately describes how unique and beautiful the Rose Bowl is as a football venue. However, he‚Äôs completely off base to advocate for the CFP national championship game to be hosted there. Unmentioned in his column is the fact that Rose Bowl's primary tenant, UCLA, is currently trying to hightail it for the sleek confines of SoFi Stadium. Does Bill really believe that the CFP management committee won‚Äôt notice?

One can add "lack of class" to Oregon's ridiculous collection of ugly uniforms based on their performance in the Orange Bowl. Leading 16-0 with less than two minutes in the game while at the Texas Tech two-yard line, the Ducks pushed across an unnecessary touchdown instead of going into the victory formation. Let's hope they get washed out in the semifinals next week.

Sorry to see Jerry Neuheisel leave UCLA to join traitor and coaching has-been Chip Kelly at Northwestern. Perhaps young Jerry will skip out after a year ‚Äî just like his boss does so often.

Having recently played Detroit, the Rams must have caught a case of "Dan Campbell-ism" that is now infecting both the NFL and college games. Definition: Going for it on fourth down while eschewing a 95% likelihood of a made field goal early in the game, all while demonstrating no confidence in your defense. Think those three points would have come in handy at the end of the Rams' loss vs. Atlanta?

The Rams' consecutive losses recently turned the McVay Rams to the Oy Vay Rams.

The only positive words for the Lakers that I read in "Pistons dominate the paint" by Thuc Nhi Nguyen were, "The Lakers have eight of their next nine games against teams with losing records." That's sad!

The Lakers coughed the ball up 21 times against the Pistons the other night. I haven't seen that many turnovers since I was at a pastry shop in Solvang.

Luka Doncic is an incredible offensive player. Maybe best in the NBA. But when you‚Äôre giving up 20-plus points in layups on the other end, your value drops significantly. ‚ÄúThe Trade‚Äù was not nearly as lopsided as everyone is saying.

Bill Plaschke's New Year's Day column on Los Angeles sports as a saving grace in very difficult times was a home run, touchdown and three-point shot all at one time. Bill had an incredibly difficult 2025, but it was inspirational to read how he was able to get through it with a love of sports getting a huge assist. To carry that theme a bit further, the world can seem so crazy, but following sports can help live and deal with it.

The Los Angeles Times welcomes expressions of all views. Letters should be brief and become the property of The Times. They may be edited and republished in any format. Each must include a valid mailing address and telephone number. Pseudonyms will not be used.

Get the best, most interesting and strangest stories of the day from the L.A. sports scene and beyond from our newsletter The Sports Report.

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

title: Manchester United explored conditions of signing Brighton‚Äôs Carlos Baleba
description: Manchester United have explored the conditions of signing Brighton & Hove Albion star Carlos Baleba in the winter transfer window.But Sky Sports report that a transfer is not expected to happen this m...
fullText:
Manchester United have explored the conditions of signing Brighton & Hove Albion star Carlos Baleba in the winter transfer window.

But Sky Sports report that a transfer is not expected to happen this month, with Brighton keen to retain the midfielder‚Äôs services until at least the summer.

United were left impressed with Baleba‚Äôs performances last season, when he made six direct goal contributions in 40 appearances across all competitions.

The Red Devils wanted to bring the 22-year-old to Old Trafford in the summer, but a transfer did not materialise due to Brighton‚Äôs enormous valuation.

Baleba hasn‚Äôt had the same impact this campaign, but United are still interested in signing him.

Ruben Amorim‚Äôs side spent the bulk of their budget on reinforcing the attack. But their priorities now lie in midfield, with the club aiming to sign at least one top central midfielder in 2026.

Casemiro cannot be relied on to play every game at 33, while Manuel Ugarte has flopped since making the move to Manchester in the summer of 2024.

There are speculations over Kobbie Mainoo‚Äôs future at United, despite his desire to stay and fight for his place.

Bruno Fernandes could also leave the club next summer due to the attractive release clause in his contract.

Besides Baleba, United have three other Premier League midfielders on their shortlist too.

Nottingham Forest‚Äôs Elliot Anderson, Crystal Palace‚Äôs Adam Wharton and Wolverhampton Wanderers‚Äô Joao Gomes have all been linked.

But a deal for any of them is expected to cost them heavily, and it remains to be seen whether they can afford to spend a lot.

title: Future of Truman Sports Complex considered after Chiefs announce move
description: Now that the Kansas City Chiefs have committed to building a new stadium and team headquarters in Kansas, what‚Äôs next for the Truman Sports Complex?
fullText:
KANSAS CITY, Mo. ‚Äî Now that the Kansas City Chiefs have committed to building a new stadium and team headquarters in Kansas, what‚Äôs next for the Truman Sports Complex?

While the Royals could still renew their lease with Jackson County, county legislator Manny Abarca says it‚Äôs time to start thinking about the future of the land.

‚ÄúAt the end of 2031, December 1, something will change and we want to be ready for that with a plan, with a strategy, if we‚Äôve got to tear down one or two stadiums, we should be prepared for that, not waiting for after the fact,‚Äù Abarca said.

Abarca wrote a letter to Jackson County Executive Phil LeVota on Wednesday, with a plan to use the existing Repair, Maintenance, Management, and Operations (RMMO) fund to set aside money for the potential demolition of one or both stadiums and the redevelopment of the land.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got to have a strategic plan going forward,‚Äù Abarca said.

‚ÄúThat opportunity of us, scrapping some of that maintenance and repair money towards the strategic plan is still within our RMMO accounts. So, there‚Äôs some opportunity. We just have to be willing to do it.‚Äù

Currently, a 3/8 cent sales tax sends roughly $55 million annually to the complex‚Äôs upkeep and renovations. Saving half of that money over the course of the next 5 years could amount to north of $137 million.

As for what‚Äôs next for the land, Abarca says it could be of huge benefit for the county.

‚ÄúI think we can look at that as a county park, as a county asset. There were houses there before and so I think there‚Äôs an opportunity to look at that as a public housing option if there aren‚Äôt stadiums there. It‚Äôs adjacent to our Rock Island corridor, which is currently a bike route, but could be a mass transit route.¬†There‚Äôs a lot of opportunity, right? Its geographic location is really center of our county.‚Äù

Whether the Royals decide to stay at Truman or leave, Abarca says it‚Äôs time to be prepared for the next phase of that land.

‚ÄúBefore taxpayers were asked to fund stadiums, this was a green space. These were neighborhoods. These were communities. There‚Äôs vibrancy that was there before. Now, instead of walking away with an abandoned stadium, that can be 30 to 50 to $70 million to tear down and maybe two of those, it can at least be a green space.‚Äù

title: Government suspends Gabon team, bans Aubameyang and sacks coach
description: Gabon's sports minister announces a series of punishments after the national team's "disgraceful performance" at the Africa Cup of Nations.
fullText:
Gabon's government has suspended the national team, banned striker Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang and sacked coach Thierry Mouyouma after their exit from the Africa Cup of Nations.

Sports Minister Simplice-Desire Mamboula announced the measures after the 3-2 defeat by Ivory Coast on 31 December.

Gabon finished bottom of their group in Morocco after earlier losses to Cameroon and Mozambique, performances Mamboula described as "disgraceful".

He said: "Given the Panthers' disgraceful performance at the Africa Cup of Nations, the government has decided to dissolve the coaching staff, suspend the national team until further notice, and exclude players Bruno Ecuele Manga and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang."

title: Prep sports recap for Dec. 31, 2025
description: PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD/WYZZ) ‚Äî Richwoods is back in the winner‚Äôs circle in Pekin. Amarion Smith-Holley scored 24 points and Tony Bradford added 14 to lead Richwoods to a 61-54 win over Chicago Mount Carmel in the title game of the 60th Pekin Insurance Holiday Tournament on Wednesday. It marks the first Pekin title for Richwoods [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD/WYZZ) ‚Äî Richwoods is back in the winner‚Äôs circle in Pekin.

Amarion Smith-Holley scored 24 points and Tony Bradford added 14 to lead Richwoods to a 61-54 win over Chicago Mount Carmel in the title game of the 60th Pekin Insurance Holiday Tournament on Wednesday. It marks the first Pekin title for Richwoods in 16 years.

‚ÄúWe hadn‚Äôt won the tournament since 2009,‚Äù said Bradford, who transferred to the Knights from Manual. ‚ÄúThis is my first year here and we are already seeing improvement. We‚Äôre winning and it feels good to come back and win.‚Äù

The Knights trailed Mount Carmel, 43-42, heading into the fourth quarter. Bradford hit a jumper from the baseline with 47 remaining to give the Knights a three-point lead and then Richwoods stole in the inbounds pass.

The win comes after 12 days after the Knights lost a 19-point lead in a 73-68 loss at Manual. Richwoods (10-2) lost a 10-point game at United Township right before the Manual game.

‚ÄúIt means a lot to turn all those L‚Äôs into lessons,‚Äù said Smith-Holley. ‚ÄúTo come in here and play hard. Every loss we had, we put behind us. We were picking everybody‚Äôs hands up. We were down in the fourth quarter but we came back.‚Äù

Also in Pekin, Springfield beat Washington, 64-57, in the tournament‚Äôs third-place game. James Johnson led the Panthers with 18 points.

Morton finished fifth at the Pekin Holiday Tournament following a 61-52 win over Chicago Leo. Alex McKie scored 19 points to lead the Potters.

Manual finished the Pontiac Holiday Tournament with a 64-49 loss to Lockport. Limestone beat host Taylorville 59-55 to take third place in the Taylorville Holiday Tournament.

title: Cori Close believes in women's sports, and needs the media to believe too
description: UCLA head coach Cori Close was frustrated with the lack of media coverage after UCLA beat Ohio State on Sunday, but postgame after UCLA's win over Penn State on Wednesday was a different story.
fullText:
LOS ANGELES - No. 4 UCLA head coach Cori Close made waves Sunday after the Bruins' thrilling victory over no. 19 Ohio State with her displeasure at the lack of media coverage for the matchup of two Big Ten powerhouses.

The Bruins outlasted the Buckeyes in an 82-75 victory on the road in a return to conference play with double-digit scoring performances by five different Bruins to secure the win. But after the game, Close was met with an empty conference room and just one reporter, Benjamin Royer of the Orange County Register, over the phone to discuss the game.

Close was frustrated, to say the least.

"If I'm being really blunt with you, the energy in the building was great, but having no media here at all from either team or either -- no AP, nothing, doesn't say a lot. We're the only double-ranked game out today; the only one in the country, and we had no media day today. No media here... Like for the only game that had two ranked opponents to not have more coverage over this particular game -- disappointing honestly, " Close said after UCLA's win (via Benjamin Royer of the Orange County Register).

UCLA women's bball coach Cori Close said that I (from Los Angeles, not in Columbus), was the only media member to to talk with her after UCLA's win vs OSU. Close said she didn't mind if I printed her response, so here it is in full.

Close's full remarks are in the photo below: pic.twitter.com/lQ3kiMcBXf

‚Äî Benjamin Royer (@thebenroyer) December 28, 2025

Close's words quickly took over over online discourse and revealed two key things: coverage of women's sports still suffers in the face of other sports, namely college football, despite the meteoric rise in popularity for women's basketball, and the overall media landscape is suffering from a lack of resources for road coverage.

When the Bruins stepped onto the court next for a dominant 97-61 over Penn State, Close and senior center Lauren Betts were met with a different sight after the game: a Zoom conference full of reporters from outlets like the Orange County Register,¬†Los Angeles Times,¬†and of course, The Sporting Tribune.

Close made it clear in her opening statement that her frustrations earlier in the week stemmed from her desire to continue to promote women's sports and the game that she loves and the passion she has for her team.

Jessica Cryderman - The Sporting Tribune

UCLA guard, Kiki Rice (1) dribbling during a NCAA basketball game against Cal Poly on December 16, 2025 in Los Angeles, CA.

"The reality of what my comments were after the Ohio State game were, I have two really passionate agendas in regards to this: I want to be a pioneer of growing the game period. I want to really be a part of the surge that's happening and and I want to be a part of telling these amazing stories that these players have, and they're incredible young women as well as amazing basketball players," Close said.

She continued, "This is nothing to take away from any men's program at all. I love men's sports just as much as I love women's sports. But, if there was a top five team all year long, and they were playing another ranked team, I don't care what time of year it would be, I think there would be more coverage there. So I just want to fight for our players getting that same proportionate coverage and exposure that I believe they've earned."

Women's basketball has experienced more growth than ever in recent years with stars like Caitlin Clark and Paige Bueckers, now both WNBA superstars with the Indiana Fever and Dallas Wings respectively, shining a massive spotlight on the sport at both the college and professional levels.

UCLA has been a part of that growth as well. An elite squad with several of their starters projected to be first-round picks in the upcoming WNBA Draft, the Bruins under Cori Close have brought a stellar brand of basketball to Westwood. Last season's Final Four-reaching squad brought in over 88,000 fans to Pauley Pavilion to watch a team that ranked no. 1 in the country for most of the season and were led by a superstar in Betts.

Jordan Teller - The Sporting Tribune

Center Lauren Betts #51 high fives guard Kiki Rice #1 of the UCLA Bruins during an NCAA basketball game against the Oregon Ducks, Sunday December 7, 2025 in Los Angeles, Calif.

Betts also spoke after the Penn State win on the issue of media coverage that the Bruins have contended.

"You have two really amazing teams, and I don't think that's something that should hopefully ever happen again [lack of coverage]," Betts said.¬†"So, just continuing to grow the game in any way that we can, and to make sure that we speak out on situations like that. But, obviously I have a lot of respect for Coach Cori and what she had to say about it."

Close has been a vocal advocate for the media and for coverage of her team and women's basketball as a whole, and the gratitude she has for reporters at her team's games is something she makes a point of stating in many postgame conferences.

Robert Talamantes- The Sporting Tribune

UCLA G Gabriela Jaquez (11) scores a fast break layup during an NCAA basketball game against the Michigan Wolverans, Wednesday January 1st, 2025 in Los Angeles, California.

There are systemic issues facing the modern sports media landscape, issues acquiring access and resources among them, but just as there are issues there has also been a proliferation of outlets that serve a wide variety of niches in the athletic world. Close wants to serve both traditional and non-traditional outlets in terms of access and availability so that she can continue shining a light on the accomplishments her team has achieved and continue to elevate women's sports as a whole.

"I always want to be solution minded. I don't want to be just a complainer," Close said. "I really want us to be a team that makes ourselves available, that gives good stories to tell... I think there needs to be access for non-traditional media outlets, as long as you're going for the right reasons, and you're really a part of wanting to tell the stories of these women. I think the days of limiting it to just traditional media outlets are over if we want to continue because.. there are so many squeezes on those traditional media outlets, I think we can't limit ourselves to what's worked in the past or how we've done things in the past."

John Panganiban-The Sporting Tribune

UCLA Bruins Coach Cori Close breaking down the game for Avary Cain (2) during an NCAA basketball game against Colgate, Sunday November 10th, 2024 in Los Angeles, California.

The impact of covering women's programs like UCLA goes well beyond entertainment factor. This new wave of women's sports popularity and the stories that athletes tell serves a humanitarian purpose as well. The inspiration that athletes can bring elevates the lives of the next generation that watches them.

Following Betts' portion of Wednesday's conference. Close shared a story that illustrates that impact potential. Betts spoke with¬†ESPN in an article published March 2025 about her mental health journey and after Wednesday's game, Close said that Betts met with one young girl waiting for an autograph that said Betts' article saved her own life. Betts came back to the locker room with happy tears in her eyes.

"That's just a real time example about why storytelling of these amazing women are so important."

title: A 2025 Year-in-Review of UNC sports in the AP Top 25
description: There‚Äôs been some ups and downs among UNC‚Äôs three big teams in 2025.
fullText:
Usually in the early part of the week, one post that gets published here at Tar Heel Blog is our weekly rundown of the AP Top 25 rankings. With football now into bowl season ‚Äî and UNC not particularly relevant in 2025 ‚Äî and basketball season in full swing, we usually take a look at the newest AP Poll and highlight where the UNC men‚Äôs and women‚Äôs basketball teams landed.

However, with there not being a particularly large amount of games last week over Christmas, the AP is not releasing new polls this week. Therefore, instead of just reposting the same rankings as last week, I thought we could use these final couple days of 2025 to look back at how the various Tar Heel teams performed in this year‚Äôs AP Top 25 rankings, which for the purposes of basketball at least, includes the end of last season.

Weeks Ranked: 8 (out of a possible 20)

Highest Ranking: #12 (first on 12/15, still currently)

UNC‚Äôs 2025 in men‚Äôs basketball has been a tale of two halves. The Tar Heels quite famously struggled on the court for much of the stretch run of last year‚Äôs basketball season, as they barely squeaked into the NCAA Tournament, having to take part in the First Four. They won a game in Dayton, but then lost to Ole Miss in the first round, ending the season on a whimper.

However, coach Hubert Davis remade the roster over the offseason, and so far it‚Äôs paid off. Caleb Wilson looks like a star, Henri Veesaar has been the perfect fit in the frontcourt, and the team has answers all over the court in general. Carolina is 12-1 on the season so far, and have a couple of potential big wins for the r√©sum√© come tournament time. They still have to prove it now in ACC play, but the Tar Heels are in a good place going into 2026.

Highest Ranking: #8 (2/24 last season)

On the other side of things, the UNC women have appeared in every AP Poll in 2025. They were a good team last year, getting an NCAA Tournament #3 seed and advancing to the Sweet 16. (The less said about what happened there, the better.) They started out this year ranked, and while they‚Äôve slid a little bit from where they started the year, they‚Äôre still on track to earn another high seed come tournament time.

Coach Courtney Banghart‚Äôs team‚Äôs issue both this season and last is that they‚Äôve been a good team, they just haven‚Äôt been able to take the step to great. They‚Äôve played games against the UConns and South Carolinas of the world, they just haven‚Äôt been able to pull off a win. The potential is certainly there for the program to get to that tier, but they‚Äôre not there yet.

End of 2024 season ranking: none

title: Plaschke: Thank you, L.A. sports teams, for saving me during the worst year
description: Will Smith, Miguel Rojas, Andy Pages, Luka Doncic and so many others delivered marquee moments that helped me endure a terrible 2025.
fullText:
It was the last story I wrote before everything changed.

It was Jan. 5, 2025, and I was marveling at the Rams gumption in their short-handed loss to the Seattle Seahawks.

‚ÄúIt was weird,‚Äù I wrote. ‚ÄúIt was wild.‚Äù

I was so witty. I was so wrong.

Two days later, I was fleeing for my life, steering my car down narrow Altadena streets with a fireball at my back and a nightmarish future sprawled across the smoke-filled streets ahead.

The year 2025 was more tumultuous than any silly football game and its accompanying overwrought metaphors. It was a year that knocked me flat, tearing me apart from so many things that once anchored me, setting me afloat in a sea of guilt and despair and ultimate uncertainty.

Today, I have a home but no home. My days are filled with the beeps and growls of bulldozers. My nights are draped in the silence of emptiness. What was once one of the coolest secrets in Los Angeles has become a veritable ghost town, the vast empty spaces populated by howling coyotes and scrounging bears.

A lot has changed in the 12 months since the Eaton Fire spared my house but destroyed my Altadena neighborhood. I say a daily prayer of thanks that I did not endure the horror of the 19 people who lost their lives and thousands more who lost their homes. I am beyond fortunate to live in what was left behind.

But virtually nothing was left behind. Venerable manicured homes have been replaced by weed-choked vacant lots. Familiar local businesses are now empty parking lots. There is the occasional sighting of new construction, but far more prevalent is ‚ÄúFor Sale‚Äù signs that have seemingly been there for months.

After living in the limbo of hotels and Airbnbs for two months while my home was remediated, I was blessed to return to four walls and running water, but beset with the guilt of having a front-row seat to the pain of so many who lost everything. I was spared, but nobody in Los Angeles was spared, and it wasn‚Äôt until halfway through the year that I noticed a consistent light from the strangest source.

Every night, I would watch the Dodgers. At least once every couple of weeks, I would attend a Sparks game with my daughter, MC. Soon, there would be Saturdays with one of our college football teams, then Sundays with the NFL then, the baseball playoffs, leading to the insane Game 7 and morphing into the annual Lakers winter drama.

The highs, the lows, the dramatics, the desperation, it was all there when nothing was there, it was the feeling that even with everything gone, you still belonged to something.

From Dodgers exhilaration to Laker despair, from USC football frustration to UCLA women‚Äôs basketball greatness, sports has been the bright wallpaper on a year of Southland darkness.

It is sports that kept me grounded, kept me steady and somehow kept me believing.

In the worst year of my life, it was sports that saved me.

The path back to normalcy began two weeks after the Eaton fire, when I left my temporary hotel room to attend a press conference for the Dodgers‚Äô latest Japanese import, Roki Sasaki.

‚ÄúInvincible,‚Äù I wrote about the team‚Äôs rebuilt roster, a word that was so comforting during such a time when everything in life felt tenuous.

I came back to the hotel after the press conference, wrote my story then, like thousands of others in my situation, packed up and moved to another hotel.

Soon thereafter I was awakened late one night with the news of the Lakers stunning acquisition of Luka Doncic. I wrote this column from a rental house while preparing to move to yet another new place. My clothes were in a plastic grocery bag. My house was still in shambles. In Doncic, as least, there was hope.

Several days later I attended the Doncic press conference, asked a question, and Doncic asked me to repeat it. Turns out, it wasn‚Äôt a language barrier, it was a sound barrier. I was speaking too softly. It was then I noticed that the trauma from the fire had exacerbated my Parkinson‚Äôs Disease, which affected my voice, one of the many symptoms which later led me to acknowledging my condition in a difficult mid-summer column.

Good news returned in early March when it was announced that the Dodgers had made Dave Roberts the richest manager in baseball, giving him a new four-year, $32.4 million contract. In a bit of dumb luck that hasn‚Äôt stopped me from bragging about it since, 10 years ago I was the first one to publicly push for Roberts‚Äô hiring. In such unstable times in our city, Roberts had become the new Tommy Lasorda, and his presence became a needed jolt of smile.

In early April, I wrote a column I never thought I‚Äôd write ‚Äî that Bronny James had been transformed from circus to contributor. I also wrote a column that I maybe wish I hadn‚Äôt written so soon, that JJ Redick was a Laker success.

In late May I sadly said goodbye to my second family when I wrote about the end of my 22-year run on ESPN‚Äôs popular ‚ÄúAround the Horn‚Äù game show. It wasn‚Äôt the first time in 2025 that a column brought me to tears, witness the video immediately after the fire. Agreed, I spent the year showing so much emotion for someone who had gotten so lucky. But I‚Äôm guessing I wasn‚Äôt alone.

Two weeks later I wrote about my new family, the group of boxers I have joined in my fight against Parkinson‚Äôs. That was the toughest column I have ever written, as I was acknowledging something I refused to admit for five years. But the fire had seemingly set the disease ablaze, and I could hide it no longer.

The year continued with columns about the soon-to-be-retiring Clayton Kershaw, the greatest Dodger pitcher with the greatest entrance song. Hearing ‚ÄúWe Are Young‚Äù when he took the mound consistently gave me hope that, through the treacheries of a summer that marked the escalation of those insane ICE raids, we can continue to strive for rebirth.

That‚Äôs what sports consistently provided in 2025, the hope that from beneath the rubble, we could all fly again.

I voiced this hope in a Rams preview column that predicted they would go to the Super Bowl. I later wrote a Rams column predicting they would actually win the Super Bowl. I stand by my stories.

All of which led to a series of Dodger playoff columns that hopefully reflected the building energy of a town enthralled. After their Game 7 victory against the Toronto Blue Jays, I was so spent that I hyperventilated for what felt like an hour.

‚ÄúIn the end, they not only ran it back, they sprinted it back, they slugged it back, and then, finally, they literally Will-ed it back,‚Äù I wrote.

In hindsight those words could have been written not only about a team, but a city, fighting back, staying strong, the results of its struggle mirroring the Dodgers‚Äô consecutive championships, punching through desperation, from struggle to strength.

In 2025, sports showed me that life can get better, life will be better, that if we hang in there long enough we can all hit that Miggy Ro homer, make that Andy Pages catch, stay forever young.

And thus I offer a heartiest and hopeful welcome to 2026.

Get the best, most interesting and strangest stories of the day from the L.A. sports scene and beyond from our newsletter The Sports Report.

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

fullText:
PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD/WYZZ) ‚Äî Five area schools took home trophies in third place games at the State Farm Classic early Tuesday.

U-High beat Fieldcrest in the small school boy‚Äôs division third-place game. Springfield Sacred Heart-Griffin beat Peoria High in the large school division third-place game, so the Lions take fourth.

Both the Eureka (small school) and Morton (large school) took home fourth place trophies in the girls third-place games at the Shirk Center on Tuesday.

title: Indiana High School Boys Basketball Rankings: Top 25 Teams ‚Äì Dec. 30
description: The Indiana high school boys basketball upcoming 2025-26 season like others across the country, is in full swing as the winter sports seasons have commenced. Continuing to top Indiana high school boys basketball are the Fishers Tigers, which is off to a sizzling 8-0 start after going 30-1 last season. The Tigers are back with plenty of [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
The Indiana high school boys basketball upcoming 2025-26 season like others across the country, is in full swing as the winter sports seasons have commenced.

Continuing to top Indiana high school boys basketball are the¬†Fishers¬†Tigers, which is off to a sizzling 8-0 start after going 30-1 last season. The Tigers are back with plenty of talent dotted along their roster, but who else should we watch for out of Indiana when it comes to the state‚Äôs top teams?

The¬†Massey Ratings, officially used during the BCS era, is a model that ranks sports teams by analyzing game outcomes, strength of schedule, and margin of victory.

Here‚Äôs a look at the top 25 high school boys basketball teams in the state of Indiana according to the¬†Massey Ratings, which ranks teams by analyzing game outcomes, strength of schedule and margin of victory, as of Dec. 30.

Fishers Tigers last year were just a bucket away from repeating as IHSA Class 4A state champions, falling in a heartbreaking, 67-66 decision to Jeffersonville. The team returns plenty of talent from a year ago as they continue to hold the No. 1 spot in our second set of Indiana high school boys basketball rankings. The Tigers brings back a pair of junior guards in¬†Jason Gardner Jr.¬†and¬†Cooper Zachary, whom combined for around 26 points per game a season ago. Coming off a 30-1 season, the Tigers remain the team to beat as they‚Äôre off to a strong start through eight games. Gardner Jr. leads the team currently in scoring at 21.3 points per contest.

Speaking of another Indiana high school boys basketball team that last year ended up falling to Jeffersonville along the way in the Class 4A state tournament was Lawrence North, as they fell to the eventual champions in a 56-49 decision. The Wildcats bring back one of the state‚Äôs top power forwards in senior¬†Brennan Miller, who averaged 13.4 points and 8.6 rebounds last season. Also watch out for forwards¬†Kai McGrew¬†and¬†Kenneth Lampley, respectively. Lawrence North has yet to drop a contest as of yet through six games.

Carmel started off the season with a football-like score of a game against No. 12 Zionsville, winning 35-28 to tip things off. Since then, the Greyhounds have been off and running through the Indiana high school boys basketball season so far. The month of January is certainly going to test the mettle of Carmel as they have matchups slated against No. 4 Cathedral (Jan. 3), No. 5 Plainfield (Jan. 16) and No. 20 Westfield (Jan. 10), respectively.

The¬†Cathedral¬†Fighting Irish dropped down a spot in our first set of regular season rankings in Indiana as they started the preseason at No. 3. Detroit Mercy commitment¬†Keaton Aldridge, who averaged 11.2 points, 5.4 rebounds, 3.4 assists last season, is back in the lineup. Another key player that‚Äôs back for the Fighting Irish this season is guard¬†Julien Smith, who was second on the team in scoring in 2024-25 at 13.5 points per game. Both players have come on strong this season for the Fighting Irish as Aldridge leads the team with 18.5 points, 9.5 rebounds a game and Smith is averaging 18.3, respectively.

Rounding out the Top 5 of the Indiana high school boys basketball rankings is the Plainfield Quakers, which went 16-8 in the 2024-25 season. The Quakers have a solid roster coming back that includes senior power forward Noah Smith, who is committed to DePaul. The three-star forward has provided the punch in the front court for Plainfield as Smith is averaging 20.6 points and 8.6 rebounds per contest this winter.

title: I've been skiing and snowboarding my whole life. Here are my 7 best tips, whether you're on the bunny hill or black diamonds.
description: After skiing and snowboarding for decades and teaching my kids the winter sports, I have great tips for first-time beginners hitting the slopes.
fullText:
I've been skiing and snowboarding my whole life, and I've even taught my children how to tackle the slopes.

Every so often, while riding the chairlift, I look down upon some out-of-control skier in soaked-through jeans, a snow-flecked sweatshirt, and cotton gloves. A few moments later, they crash into some obstacle and tangle themselves among their skis and poles.

It reminds me that although these sports can be fun winter activities, if you're not properly dressed or prepared, you're putting yourself and others at risk.

Whether you're a beginner or a seasoned pro, here are a few tips for staying safe on the mountain.

Slope safety begins at home. Before you leave, consider your outfit.

You'll definitely want waterproof snow pants and a jacket that will keep the wind and rain off of you, but your layers don't have to be anything fancy.

To start, you may be able to cobble together something warm from what you already own. Try wool sweaters, synthetic running shirts, and that random fleece vest that you own but never wear.

I think it's pointless for a new skier to drop hundreds of dollars on gear, but there are a few body parts worth investing in (hands, feet, head). If you're going to spend money on anything, invest in good gloves.

Beyond that, ski socks are priceless in keeping toes warm. A good neck gaiter and a basic pair of goggles can prevent your nose and eyes from dripping icicles, too.

When picking out your gear, keep in mind that anything made of cotton has no place on the mountain.

When cotton gets wet ‚Äî an inevitability for first-time skiers and snowboarders who spend a lot of time on the ground or anyone who's prone to sweating ‚Äî the material absorbs the moisture, remains wet, and makes you cold.

Choose synthetic materials or natural fibers like wool that help to wick away water from the body and keep you warm.

Whether you're renting or investing in your first pair of ski or snowboard boots, know that they should be snug.

The boots are meant to react to your feet's movements, so they have to be a little tight. However, they shouldn't be cutting off your circulation.

If they're uncomfortable in the rental shop, they're going to feel terrible on the mountain.

Do yourself a favor and make sure they feel as close to perfect as possible before you hit the chairlift. The employees in ski shops should be able to help.

Once you arrive at the mountain, don't look to tackle anything above your level.

If you're a beginner, head straight for the bunny slopes. There's no shame in learning to turn, stop, and not kill yourself or someone else on the mountain's gentlest run.

The fastest way to get off the bunny hill is to take a one-hour lesson to help you acquire the basic skills to become a more competent rider.

After you gain the fundamentals, progress in order. Conquering the bunny hill doesn't mean you're ready for black diamonds.

Head to green-circle beginner trails to practice your turns and technique. After getting comfortable with those skills on that terrain, try the blue-square intermediate trails.

Pro tip: Keep in mind that trail markings are not universal from mountain to mountain. A black diamond in the Poconos usually isn't as difficult as a black diamond in Colorado.

We're heading into 2026 and not the aughts ‚Äî a time when people didn't seem to truly understand that speed, hard surfaces, and bare skulls made for dangerous combinations on the slopes.

Whether you're a beginner or a pro, you'll want a helmet. You can usually rent these if needed.

Taking an in-person lesson is the best way to really get the hang of skiing, but here are a few tips and stances to get you started.

First-time skiers need to remember two foods: pizza and french fries.

Keep a gentle bend in your knees and shape your skis like a slice of pizza to achieve a more controlled stance, then proceed down the mountain at a reduced speed. Thinner pizza slices make you go faster, and wider ones slow you down.

When you're ready to go faster, shaping your skis more parallel, like french fries, will send you straight down.

Snowboarders have fewer food terms to remember, but you'll want to loosely bend your knees and carve back and forth across the mountain to limit your speed.

The trickiest part of snowboarding is shifting from your heel to your toe to change directions.

My best advice is to start slow, commit to every turn, and look where you want to go (not backward).

This story was originally published on December 3, 2024, and most recently updated on December 30, 2025.

title: In a Year of Violent Tumult, the Sports World Was Silent
description: Dave...
fullText:
In this time of unrelenting, often unprecedented cruelty and lawlessness, I‚Äôm grateful for Nation readers like you.

So many of you have taken to the streets, organized in your neighborhood and with your union, and showed up at the ballot box to vote for progressive candidates. You‚Äôre proving that it is possible‚Äîto paraphrase the legendary Patti Smith‚Äîto redeem the work of the fools running our government.

And as we head into 2026, I promise that The Nation will fight like never before for justice, humanity, and dignity in these United States.

At a time when most news organizations are either cutting budgets or cozying up to Trump by bringing in right-wing propagandists, The Nation‚Äôs writers, editors, copy editors, fact-checkers, and illustrators confront head-on the administration‚Äôs deadly abuses of power, blatant corruption, and deconstruction of both government and civil society.

We couldn‚Äôt do this crucial work without you.

Through the end of the year, a generous donor is matching all donations to The Nation‚Äôs independent journalism up to $75,000. But the end of the year is now only days away.

Time is running out to have your gift doubled. Don‚Äôt wait‚Äîdonate now to ensure that our newsroom has the full $150,000 to start the new year.

Another world really is possible. Together, we can and will win it!

title: WMBD Sports Recap: Illini, BU, ISU, ICC women all win, HS holiday tournament recap (Dec. 29, 2025)
description: Editor‚Äôs Note: The Illinois State game highlights cannot be shown on this clip because they were pulled from a game feed. PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD) ‚Äì The Illini beat Southern, Bradley defeated Evansville, and Illinois State cruised past Drake Monday. The Braves and Redbirds both stay unbeaten in MVC play. ICC women won over North Central [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
Editor‚Äôs Note: The Illinois State game highlights cannot be shown on this clip because they were pulled from a game feed.

PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD) ‚Äì The Illini beat Southern, Bradley defeated Evansville, and Illinois State cruised past Drake Monday. The Braves and Redbirds both stay unbeaten in MVC play.

ICC women won over North Central Missouri to advance to the title game of their tournament.

In high school holiday tournaments, Elmwood beat Brimfield in the Princeville tournament title game while Midland defeated Princeville in the 3rd place game. In the girls bracket, Elmwood beat Midland for the trophy and Tremont earned 3rd.

At the State Farm Holiday Classic, Normal Community boys and Washington girls advanced to their respective Large School bracket title games.

Peoria boys, U-High boys, Fieldcrest boys, and Eureka girls will settle for appearances in the third place games.

At the opening day of the Pekin tournament, Richwoods, Washington and Morton all advanced to the winner‚Äôs bracket.

In the first round of the Pontiac tournament, Manual won their opening round game to move to the quarterfinals while Bloomington and Pontiac lost.

Tremont and Dee-Mack boys will meet in the 3rd-place game of the Williamsville Holiday tournament.

Dee-Mack girls advanced to the title game at the North Mac Tournament with a 50-18 win over Pawnee.

title: Tennis star Venus Williams marries actor and model Andrea Preti in lavish second wedding at $10 million Florida estate
description: The wedding lasted five days and included a bridal shower, pool parties and sports events.
fullText: Realtor.comTennis star Venus Williams marries actor and model Andrea Preti in lavish second wedding at $10 million Florida estateThe wedding lasted 5 days.ShareResizeListen(5 min)Tennis legend¬†Venus Williams and her spouse, model¬†Andrea Preti, have said ‚ÄúI do‚Äù a second time during a lavish five-day wedding at their sprawling¬†Florida¬†home.Williams, 45, and Preti, 38, first tied the knot in September in Italy. At the time, they didn‚Äôt have enough time to file paperwork, so they opted for another wedding, as reported by¬†Vogue.

title: Five Bears whose stock went up or down in NFL Week 17 loss to 49ers
description: Nicholas Moreano identifies five Chicago Bears players whose stock went up or down in an NFL Week 17 road loss to the San Francisco 49ers. The post Five Bears whose stock went up or down in NFL Week 17 loss to 49ers appeared first on Marquee Sports Network - Home of the Cubs, Bears, Red Stars and Sky.
fullText:
The final Sunday in 2025 provided football fans with a memorable game that featured plenty of offensive firepower.

With how the Chicago Bears and San Francisco 49ers moved the ball and scored, it felt like a game that would end with whatever team had the ball last.

Caleb Williams and the Bears had their shot with 2:15 left in the game, down by four points.

The Bears quarterback led his team on a 15-play drive that ended on the 49ers‚Äô 2-yard line after Williams attempted to extend the play to find an open receiver. With the 49ers‚Äô defense closing in, Williams threw a pass into the end zone, but it fell short.

Wild ending to an incredible game. pic.twitter.com/Xe6pJkBfEa

The Bears lost 42-38, which eliminates them from contention for the NFC‚Äôs No. 1 playoff seed. Still, as NFC North champions, they will host at least one playoff game at Soldier Field.

Here are the five players who raised and lowered their stock in the Week 17 shootout at Levi‚Äôs Stadium.

Williams had one of his best passing performances of the season, completing 25 of 42 throws for 330 yards and two touchdowns.

His first TD pass of the day ‚Äî to rookie Luther Burden III ‚Äî was a perfectly thrown 35-yard strike in the first quarter.

Caleb Williams drops it in a basket for the Luther Burden III touchdown

‚Äî Marquee Sports Network (@WatchMarquee) December 29, 2025

Williams‚Äô second TD pass ‚Äî to Colston Loveland in the second quarter‚Äì displayed some of his elite quarterback traits. Williams drew the 49ers‚Äô defense offside with his cadence, kept his eyes downfield after the snap, then threw a dart to his rookie tight end for a 36-yard score.

Caleb Williams gets the 49ers on the hard count.

Touchdown, Colston Loveland

‚Äî Marquee Sports Network (@WatchMarquee) December 29, 2025

With how well the 49ers‚Äô offense played, Williams needed to match Brock Purdy on the other side. For a majority of the game, that‚Äôs exactly what he did. However, he missed some throws.

On the final drive, Williams was heavily pressured on a first-and-10 play. He ran away from the pressure to his right but couldn‚Äôt complete a pass to wide-open Devin Duvernay on what might have been a game-winning TD.

this was 7 pic.twitter.com/WzuR5ONtEM

‚Äî Warren Sharp (@SharpFootball) December 29, 2025

It only took one play for the former All-Pro cornerback to change the game.

Johnson jumped Jauan Jennings‚Äô slant route and deflected Purdy‚Äôs first pass on the first play of the game into the air. T.J. Edwards intercepted the ball and returned it 34 yards for a pick six.

T.J. EDWARDS, PICK-SIX ON THE FIRST PLAY OF THE GAME

‚Äî Marquee Sports Network (@WatchMarquee) December 29, 2025

Johnson finished the game with zero receptions allowed on one target. He wasn‚Äôt targeted for the remainder of the game after helping cause the pick six, but he also played limited snaps in the second half.

Johnson has given up just seven receptions on 12 targets for 142 yards in six games this season, and he has one interception. It shows just how important keeping Johnson healthy is to the Bears‚Äô defense.

The Bears‚Äô rookie wide receiver returned to action after missing last week‚Äôs win over the Green Bay Packers and quickly made an impact.

Entering their third drive, the Bears had failed to record a first down. Then Williams found Burden for a 10-yard gain on second down. Three plays later, Williams connected with Burden on an explosive 35-yard TD pass, giving Chicago‚Äôs offense its first points of the game late in the first quarter.

Caleb Williams drops it in a basket for the Luther Burden III touchdown

‚Äî Marquee Sports Network (@WatchMarquee) December 29, 2025

Burden finished as the game‚Äôs leading receiver with eight receptions on nine targets for 138 yards and the TD. He was injured on the final play of the game, and head coach Ben Johnson didn‚Äôt have an immediate update on the rookie‚Äôs condition.

The Bears‚Äô veteran linebacker had the daunting task of trying to contain Christian McCaffrey. The entire defense, especially Edmunds, failed to keep the 49ers‚Äô versatile playmaker in check.

McCaffrey finished the first half with 18 carries for 121 yards and one TD. He added two receptions for 20 yards as a pass catcher before halftime.

: NBC
NFL+// https://t.co/Zkva0Y3QRRpic.twitter.com/Lw0glXcnaP

‚Äî San Francisco 49ers (@49ers) December 29, 2025

Per Pro Football Focus, Edmunds allowed seven receptions on seven targets for 55 yards and two TDs.

The 49ers‚Äô offense, which features plenty of motions and shifts, forced Edmunds and the rest of the Bears‚Äô defensive front to react slowly, and San Francisco benefited throughout the game, finishing with 496 total yards (200 rushing, 296 passing).

The Bears cornerback dealt with a hamstring injury and an illness throughout the week, but he was able to start against the 49ers.

He‚Äôs had a remarkable season, but this wasn‚Äôt a good showing. Per Pro Football Focus, Wright gave up four receptions on five targets for 73 yards in just the first half.

Wright looked a step slow and couldn‚Äôt stay in front of opposing receivers.

The post Five Bears whose stock went up or down in NFL Week 17 loss to 49ers appeared first on Marquee Sports Network - Home of the Cubs, Bears, Red Stars and Sky.

title: Falcons rumor from FOX Sports sets course for Matt Ryan reunion
description: The latest Atlanta Falcons rumor from FOX Sports sets the course for a reunion between the Falcons and former MVP quarterback Matt Ryan.
fullText:
Falcons rumor from FOX Sports sets course for Matt Ryan reunion originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Matt Ryan was the starting quarterback of the Atlanta Falcons for nearly 15 years from 2008 to 2021, and though the 40-year-old's playing days are long over, it looks like a reunion between Ryan and the Falcons could be on the way.

According to FOX Sports' Jay Glazer, Atlanta has had conversations with Ryan about coming back to the franchise to serve in the front office. Ryan's role in the front office would be significant, and the former All-Pro signal-caller is heavily considering taking the job.

"Scoopage: Atlanta Falcons have had conversations with their former Pro Bowl QB Matt Ryan about rejoining the Falcons in a front office role. While two sides still discussing, people close to Ryan say he‚Äôs seriously considering this move and talks are ongoing. It would be for a significant role in the front office," Glazer said on X.

Ryan is a Falcons legend and clearly has an advanced football brain, as he played quarterback at a high level for multiple years and has become a respected analyst on CBS Sports since retiring in 2024.

Atlanta hasn't made the playoffs since 2017. Funny enough, Ryan was the quarterback of the last Falcons' squad that qualified for the postseason.

It's clear that change is needed for the Falcons, and though Ryan can no longer play quarterback and lead the franchise to wins, he could serve as a key piece in the front office that turns the team around.

This offseason, Atlanta will need to evaluate their quarterback room, as Michael Penix Jr. is recovering from ACL surgery¬†and Kirk Cousins is no longer a starting-caliber player. There's no better person to have in the front office with an uncertain quarterback situation than a former MVP signal-caller in Ryan.

title: üö® SGE sign star striker in record Bundesliga winter deal
description: A few days after Christmas Eve, sports director Markus Kr√∂sche gave all fans supporting Eintracht Frankfurt a belated Christmas present!As reported by 'Sky' and 'Bild' on Sunday evening, Younes Ebnou...
fullText:
A few days after Christmas Eve, sports director Markus Kr√∂sche gave all fans supporting Eintracht Frankfurt a belated Christmas present!

As reported by 'Sky' and 'Bild' on Sunday evening, Younes Ebnouatlib will transfer from SV 07 Elversberg to SGE in January. Only the medical check is pending.

The 22-year-old will cost a transfer fee of eight million euros, making him the most expensive Bundesliga transfer of this winter so far. Including bonuses, Elversberg could even receive up to ten million euros for Ebnouatlib.

The 1.91m tall striker is one of the biggest discoveries of this second division season, having scored 12 goals in 17 appearances. It is mainly because of him that SVE greets the new year from an outstanding second place in the standings.

But in the middle of the season, Ebnouatlib is now moving up a level. The rising star is expected to address the severe personnel issues in Frankfurt's attacking center.

Due to the absences of Jonathan Burkardt and Michy Batshuayi, as well as Elye Wahi's lack of form, there is a significant gap in SGE's front line. Therefore, another goal scorer is likely to be signed in the coming days, with Arnaud Kalimuendo considered the most promising candidate.
